Kenneth Stanley wrote:

>>Hey Colin, just out of curiosity what was the fine tuning that
>>improved things?  
>>
>>
>>    
>>
Hi Ken,

I'll probably write up what I did in detail on the web site, just 
quickly though I had a think about what you said about randomization in 
the trials, so whereas before I used 100 randomized trials and gradually 
increased the difficulty by giving the prey 0 to 4 initial moves an then 
increasing it's speed, I am now running 32 predefined trials. 16 tests 
with the prey starting within sensor range and not moving and another 16 
using the same start positions but allowing the prey 3 initial moves. 
The initial moves are also deterministic in that the prey moves directly 
away from the agent and this also has the effect of moving the prey out 
of sensor range - by then though the agent has received inputs with the 
prey's location, so it has chance to remember where they prey was seen. 
These tests are passed 100% but do not produce a perfect agent - it 
still can't chase moving prey with a 4 move head start in all test 
cases, although it does perform pretty well actually :). Anyway this 
situation should be resolvable by extending the trials to contain 
further more difficult tests or by switching completely to a more 
difficult trial  i.e.incremental evolution.  In fact I may be able to 
revert to my original randomized trials once a good population has been 
found.

Colin.
